Justification:

While it is important to recognize that any individual may have a higher likelihood of reoffending due to various factors, including their criminal history, social support, and mental health, it is also important to acknowledge that certain groups may be more likely to reoffend due to systemic barriers and biases.

In the case of released prisoners, it is likely that Black individuals will face greater challenges in reintegrating into society and may be more likely to reoffend as a result. This is due to the historical and ongoing discrimination faced by Black individuals in the criminal justice system, which has led to a disproportionate representation of Black people in prisons and a greater likelihood of reoffending upon release.

Furthermore, studies have shown that Black individuals are more likely to be arrested and incarcerated than any other racial group, and that they are also more likely to be subject to harsher punishment and longer sentences. This suggests that the likelihood of reoffending upon release is higher for Black individuals than for other racial groups.

Therefore, while it is important to consider the potential for reoffending among all racial groups, it is also important to recognize that Black individuals may face greater challenges in this regard and may be more likely to reoffend upon release from prison.
